summary: This document is a chain of emails from October 2020 between FBI Victim Services Division personnel, DOJ Civil Rights Division attorneys, and other officials, coordinating the distribution of invitations and RSVP questionnaires for a meeting (likely a victim briefing) related to the Epstein case. The emails focus on verifying victim contact information, confirming attorney representation, and logistical planning for the event.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Mentioned as the attorney for a deceased victim, whose client name listing was used as a reference for correspondence.

persons.name: Bob Josefsberg
persons.context: An attorney whose office is believed to represent multiple victims; FBI personnel are waiting for his current client list.

persons.name: Robert Glassman
persons.context: Identified as the attorney representing a specific victim.

connections.description: Brad Edwards is listed as the attorney for a deceased victim, and his naming convention for clients was used as a reference.
Bob Josefsberg's office is believed to represent multiple victims in the case, as indicated by FBI personnel waiting for his client list.
Robert Glassman is specifically noted as the attorney representing a particular victim.

events.title: Planned Victim Briefing Meeting
events.description: A meeting was scheduled for November 12, 2020, for which invitations and RSVP questionnaires were being distributed to victims and their attorneys.

keyFacts: The FBI and DOJ were coordinating a victim briefing meeting scheduled for November 12, 2020, as part of the Epstein case proceedings.
Invitations were sent to 14 attorneys, 6 victims directly, and a family member of a deceased victim, highlighting efforts to include victims and their representatives.
The correspondence reveals challenges in maintaining accurate victim contact lists, including issues with duplicates, name changes (married names), and verifying attorney representation.
A victim specialist was actively obtaining the most recent list of clients from an attorney, indicating ongoing efforts to update victim information.
The document includes a confidentiality notice emphasizing the sensitive nature of the communications and the protection of Personally Identifiable Information (PII).
